body:
This isn't a bug, you need to handle the `new-window` event to do this:

``` coffee
    webView.on 'new-window', (e) ->
      try
        theUrl = url.parse e.url
        throw new Error("Invalid protocol") unless theUrl.protocol in ['http:', 'https:', 'mailto:']

        require('shell').openExternal(e.url)
      catch error
        console.log "Ignoring #{e.url} due to #{error.message}"
```

I had already tried that.  I never get the event. 

Here is part of my code.  I get the loading event when I load the page but I never get the new-window event.  I tried clicking on a link and ctrl-clicking.

```
@content: ->
  @div class:'browser-page', tabindex:-1, =>
    @tag 'webview'

initialize: (page) ->
  @webview = @find('webview')[0]

  $(@webview).on 'did-start-loading', (e)->
    console.log 'did-start-loading event'

  $(@webview).on 'new-window', (e)->
    console.log 'new-window event'
```

BTW, how is the new-window event handler supposed to know whether it is a click or a ctrl-click?

I think you are wrong about the new-window event.  This is from the specs file.  Note that it only fires new-window when the link has a target.  Most don't.  The ones I'm clicking don't have targets.

```
  describe 'new-window event', ->
    it 'emits when window.open is called', (done) ->
      webview.addEventListener 'new-window', (e) ->
        assert.equal e.url, 'http://host'
        assert.equal e.frameName, 'host'
        done()
      webview.src = "file://#{fixtures}/pages/window-open.html"
      document.body.appendChild webview

    it 'emits when link with target is called', (done) ->
      webview.addEventListener 'new-window', (e) ->
        assert.equal e.url, 'http://host/'
        assert.equal e.frameName, 'target'
        done()
      webview.src = "file://#{fixtures}/pages/target-name.html"
      document.body.appendChild webview
```

This bug report is that normal links don't work.  I can't navigate anywhere like I can in an iFrame.

Can you push your package somewhere so I can test?

> BTW, how is the new-window event handler supposed to know whether it is a click or a ctrl-click?

See the `disposition` parameter of `new-window`:
https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/blob/master/docs/api/web-view-tag.md#new-window

It's at https://github.com/mark-hahn/web-browser/tree/dbg-shell

Use ctrl-alt-B and type in e.g. apple.com.

It seems to work fine on my side:
![source-map](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/639601/5177496/1cfeacf2-7495-11e4-8420-d205c10a3ab6.gif)

You used branch dbg-shell?  Master still uses iFrame.

Maybe just search for webview in the project.

How hard would it be for me to debug it?

I also tested on Windows and it worked fine, and no others users of `<webview>` reported similar problems. It is mysterious to me that you had this problem, and I'm afraid debugging this would require digging into atom-shell's C++ code to find out why.

My web-browser package, which is quite popular, is pretty much dead without webview.  iFrame has many problems and missing features.

Would you want to remote into my PC?   Or, tell me what tools I have to install to debug this myself.

I installed it only my windows laptop and it worked fine.  There are two problems with it not working on my dev machine ..
- It is very inconvenient
- Where there is smoke there is fire.  There is some problem that needs to be fixed.  Even if it is only broken on one out of 10 PCs it is a serious problem.

So I (we) still need to proceed to debug it.  We cannot ignore it.
In my app, `new-window` fires even when links don't have a target

@zcbenz, upgrading to atom 0.152.0 seems to have fixed it.  So I can quit worrying.

@paulcbetts, on both my working setups I only see `new-window` when I ctrl-click.  So mine is matching the docs.  Now we have the mystery of why you are getting new-window when you are not supposed to.  (grin)  What atom-shell are you on?  I'm on 0.19.4.
@mark-hahn This is on 0.19.4 as well, the official build (i.e. downloaded via `grunt-download-atom-shell`)

The problem is back but on my laptop.  So it has happened separately on two PCs.  I switched to the exact code that had worked before and it didn't help.  Also It has been seen on both atom 151 and 152.

I'll do everything I can to find out what triggers it but I think this is going to be a tough one to isolate.  We may have to go back to the strategy of debugging the webview code.

The comment that others have not seen the problem doesn't really mean much in this situation.  I am using it heavily and it is intermittent.

**Edit:** I turned off other packages and the problem went away.  Then I turned the packages back on and webview kept working.  So it was probably a coincidence.  The next time it fails I will repeat that experiment.
WebView right now is pretty touchy, there are a lot of situations where it does Weird Stuff™, like if you set `display:none` or set its size to 0x0, then try to set it back

I am close to being able to repeat my problem.  It has something to do with
bringing up settings and then turning packages on and off.

>  if you set display:none

There is a chance I do this.  I'll check it out.  Do you think webview is
flakey from Google or Atom/shell?

@mark-hahn WebView is entirely Atom Shell at the moment, it only mimics the design of Chrome's WebView tag. I'm about to start filing bugs and (hopefully) start to fix them too

That would be great.  My web-browser package's feature set is frozen at the
moment because I can't get anything more out of an iFrame implementation.
With webview it can pretty much be a real web browser. Its real purpose is
to provide in-editor debugging cycles but that also needs webview.

@paulcbetts Can you print the `disposition` parameter of the `new-window` event?

> I'm about to start filing bugs and (hopefully) start to fix them too

Is it OK to bug you about this?  I'm really itching to use webview in `web-browser` to fix issues and add new features.
BTW, in case this thread isn't clear, the show-stopper bug is the one you mentioned where display:none throws an exception.  Webview is useless in Atom because of this.
Just use `visibility` or change the size to 0x0, both of those work

That is not possible.  My code is just in a tab item and core code changes
tabs.  In general the editor reserves the right to hide anything it feels
like.  Entire panes can be hidden.

Is webview written in C++ or JS?  If JS then it would probably be easy for
me to fix webview and do a PR.  I could also debug C++, it's just that I am
a bit rusty in that area.

Do you have any idea what could be causing the problem?

On Thu, Dec 18, 2014 at 10:57 PM, Paul Betts notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Just use visibility or change the size to 0x0, both of those work
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/852#issuecomment-67604693.

@mark-hahn As I recall, the core issue is related to event handlers and other objects being tied to the DOM element, which because of `display:none` has been removed from memory (`display:none` elements in Chrome are deallocated)

That's weird.  I am misunderstanding something.

Aren't there tons of things tied to hidden dom elements all the time?  What is special about these objects that makes them "weak"?
@mark-hahn Yeah - app developers (i.e. people writing JS) shouldn't have to think about this at all, this is an Atom Shell bug that is incorrectly leaking out

Is it in C++?  I can work on it.

> BTW, in case this thread isn't clear, the show-stopper bug is the one you mentioned where display:none throws an exception. Webview is useless in Atom because of this.

This bug is tracked in upstream at https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=419020, there is a fix for our case already, but we have to wait Chrome40 or Chrome41 to be able to import the fix, because it relies on some big changes in content module.

> This patch is also a big step towards guest teleportation.

Damn, teleportation? Rio, here I come!

Awesome. Thanks for the info.

WTF?
